Author: TonyL#3577
Content: Just returned from holiday. Gonna wrap head quickly over the progress and proceed with the testing

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: my tests show that as long as you dont exceed the p2p network capacity (determined by the network topology and speed of nodes), then only about 1 in a million packets are out of sync

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: with low end nodes, we saw the limit at about 3000/sec

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: with higher end nodes, around 10000/sec

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: txpow is active now at a minimal level and it would take a lot of cores to reach 10,000/sec

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i dont have priority based routing implemented yet, but the idea is that if the network is under spam attack, the nodes could detect this and increase the priority level they broadcast at. so without changing "consensus" limits, each client can increase the priority level until it sees all its packets arriving in the peer nodes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the one hour limit is a bit arbitrary and can be increased, but it doesnt seem like too much overhead for a GTC order to have to broadcast once per hour

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i imagine realtime games designed for UDP could work without too much changes to use -dexp2p mode

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i just updated (untested yet) using nServices bits to let other nodes know if dexp2p is supported, also made it so komodod -nSPV=1 nodes (superlite) will be able to do dexp2p messages. there are no nSPV remote access commands for dexp2p data (yet), but the plan is to add that and nodes with dexp2p=2 will be the fullnodes that respond to such requests, with dexp2p=1 nodes not responding

Content: @gcharang i think it is ready to start documenting -dexp2p mode

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: for now it is just in my DEX branch, at some point it will be possible to make it compatible with normal branches (ie. not allocate a bunch of static data)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: @TonyL @gcharang while dexp2p is designed specifically for DEX orderbooks it is done in a general way so that many other usecases are directly supported. tagA and tagB would be "base" and "rel" (or maker and taker) orders, which can also have a volA and volB field. this will allow the dexp2p to create an orderbook with volumes and price of tagA/tagB

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the destpubkey is so you can send a DM to a specific address and even though it will be broadcast to all nodes, the data will be encrypted. with network analysis, the sender can be identified (the node who first broadcasts it) and the destpubkey is in plaintext, so the fact that a specific ip address is sending encrypted traffic to a specific pubkey can be determined. though, similar to GRIN it would take having a lot of monitoring nodes nearly fully connected to all the network to find the ip address, so it isnt anything that is easy to do, but then again not too difficult

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if privacy of the sending ip is needed, do not use this for such comms

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: wow, so pubkey is for OTC inside the DEX network

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: in most cases other people knowing that an ip address (even if identified as you) is known to be sending messages to a brand new and never used anywhere else pubkey, it seems that is very little info leaked

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you can implement a discord type of channel based public comms with DM using this, and by discord type, i mean tagA == name of discord, tagB == channel

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so you can be connected to multiple dexp2p-discords, each with their own set of channels and send DM to specific pubkeys. you can publish your pubkey and even with monitoring of all traffic, it shouldnt leak that you send a DM, but of course if you link yourself to a pubkey, anything sent to you will be known you got messages, so to keep privacy, have 2 pubkeys. one that is public and linked to your handle, another (one for each other person) that is known only to you and the other person. this is exchanges in the public DM.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this way, you can get a persons secret pubkey and DM to that and nobody would know who the destination is. but as you can see, using this system for private comms will take a bit of extra work

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is designed for speed above all else and will drop sync to maintain speed of following the realtime messages

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: why broadcasting node might set not max `priority` ?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: each priority level increase, doubles the time to calculate the txPoW

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: priority of 10 is 1024 times harder to find that priority 0

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: so if I want more "prioritized" orders I need better server?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and currently priority 0 is equivalent to an internal priority level of 12

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: bigger is better

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but unless the network is overloaded, all messages get through, other than the background loss of 1 in a million

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: is time for txPoW is const  and not depends of my CPU freq?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is SHA256 hash with enough 0 bits

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: actually it starts with the lowest bits matching 0x777

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then additional 0 bits on top

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 12 bits for 0x777 seems to take a few milliseconds

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: I see, so hardware matters just a little bit

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it wont be noticeable even on a slow system

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: at a priority of 5, i think it will take about 1 second

Author: TonyL#3577
Content:
`DEX_list stopat minpriority tagA tagB destpub33 [minA maxA minB maxB]` last param I wanted to clarify:
is `stopat` in `DEX_list` a unix timestamp?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the idea is that if you dont see your orders appear in the orderbook (from a remote nSPV request) and there are indications that the network is lagging, then boost the priority. that will then give preference to your packets. [this routing preference is not implemented yet]
